name: Eggplant Agebitashi
description: Deep-fried until crispy then soaked in a savory broth, tender Eggplant Agebitashi could be your new favorite way to enjoy Japanese eggplant. I lightly score the eggplant so it cooks faster and absorbs the delicious dashi and soy sauce flavors. {Vegan Adaptable}

video.name: How To Make Eggplant Agebitashi (Recipe) 茄子の揚げ浸しの作り方 （レシピ）
video.description:
Eggplant Agebitashi is Japanese eggplant deep fried and soaked in a flavorful dashi broth, topped with grated daikon and ginger.

PRINT RECIPE ▶ http://www.justonecookbook.com/eggplant-agebitashi/

Ingredients:

2 Japanese eggplants
2 cups (500 ml) cooking oil (vegetable, canola)
3 inch (7.5 cm) daikon (green top part for sweet taste)
1 green onion/scallion
1 inch (2.5 cm) ginger
1 pack (3 g) katsuobushi (bonito flakes)

Sauce
¾ cup (200 ml) dashi
3 Tbsp. (40 ml) mirin
3 Tbsp. (40 ml) sake
3 Tbsp. (40 ml) soy sauce
1 heaping Tbsp. (15 g) sugar

Instructions ▶ http://www.justonecookbook.com/eggplant-agebitashi/

recipeIngredient: 2  Japanese or Chinese eggplants ((10 oz, 283 g))
3 inches daikon radish ((use the green top part for a sweet taste))
1 knob ginger ((1 inch, 2.5 cm per knob))
⅓ cup katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) ((skip for vegan/vegetarian))

recipeInstructions.text: In a saucepan, combine the broth ingredients: ¾ cup dashi (Japanese soup stock), 3 Tbsp mirin, 3 Tbsp sake, 3 Tbsp soy sauce, and 1 heaping Tbsp sugar. Mix it all together. Bring it to a boil and turn off the heat. Keep it covered so the broth doesn’t evaporate.
recipeInstructions.name: In a saucepan, combine the broth ingredients: ¾ cup dashi (Japanese soup stock), 3 Tbsp mirin, 3 Tbsp sake, 3 Tbsp soy sauce, and 1 heaping Tbsp sugar. Mix it all together. Bring it to a boil and turn off the heat. Keep it covered so the broth doesn’t evaporate.

recipeInstructions.text: In a deep-frying pot/saucepan, add 2 cups neutral oil and bring it to 320ºF (160ºC). While waiting for the oil, prepare the eggplants.
recipeInstructions.name: In a deep-frying pot/saucepan, add 2 cups neutral oil and bring it to 320ºF (160ºC). While waiting for the oil, prepare the eggplants.

itemListElement.text: You must cut the eggplant right before deep-frying to avoid discoloration. First, discard the tops of 2 Japanese or Chinese eggplants and cut in half lengthwise. Tip: While we usually soak eggplant in water to prevent discoloration, we will not soak in water for this recipe because we will deep-fry it without a coating.
itemListElement.name: You must cut the eggplant right before deep-frying to avoid discoloration. First, discard the tops of 2 Japanese or Chinese eggplants and cut in half lengthwise. Tip: While we usually soak eggplant in water to prevent discoloration, we will not soak in water for this recipe because we will deep-fry it without a coating.

itemListElement.text: Lightly score the eggplant with diagonal incisions on the skin side at ⅛-inch (3-mm) intervals. You could also score in a crisscross pattern. Do not cut through.
itemListElement.name: Lightly score the eggplant with diagonal incisions on the skin side at ⅛-inch (3-mm) intervals. You could also score in a crisscross pattern. Do not cut through.

itemListElement.text: After scoring, cut each piece into 3–4 sections. Make sure to wipe off any moisture with a paper towel.
itemListElement.name: After scoring, cut each piece into 3–4 sections. Make sure to wipe off any moisture with a paper towel.

itemListElement.text: Check if the oil has reached at 320ºF (160ºC) with an instant-read thermometer or by sticking wooden chopsticks into the oil. If you see small bubbles forming around the tips, the oil is ready.
itemListElement.name: Check if the oil has reached at 320ºF (160ºC) with an instant-read thermometer or by sticking wooden chopsticks into the oil. If you see small bubbles forming around the tips, the oil is ready.

itemListElement.text: Gently place a few pieces of eggplant in the oil, skin side down, and deep-fry for 2 to 2½ minutes. Fry in batches and do not overcrowd the pot. Remove from the oil and drain on a wire rack, skin side up. Repeat until all the eggplant pieces are deep-fried. Tip: When you deep-fry, do not crowd the pot because the oil temperature will drop quickly. Your ingredients should take up no more than about half of the oil surface area at any one time. If the oil temperature gets too low, take out the eggplant and wait until the oil reaches the right temperature. For more helpful hints, read my post How to Deep-Fry Food.
itemListElement.name: Gently place a few pieces of eggplant in the oil, skin side down, and deep-fry for 2 to 2½ minutes. Fry in batches and do not overcrowd the pot. Remove from the oil and drain on a wire rack, skin side up. Repeat until all the eggplant pieces are deep-fried. Tip: When you deep-fry, do not crowd the pot because the oil temperature will drop quickly. Your ingredients should take up no more than about half of the oil surface area at any one time. If the oil temperature gets too low, take out the eggplant and wait until the oil reaches the right temperature. For more helpful hints, read my post How to Deep-Fry Food.

itemListElement.text: When the eggplants have cooled, place them skin side up in a rimmed container or dish. Heat the broth until hot, then pour it over the eggplants to soak for at least 1 hour and up to several hours. To serve this dish chilled, put it in the refrigerator.
itemListElement.name: When the eggplants have cooled, place them skin side up in a rimmed container or dish. Heat the broth until hot, then pour it over the eggplants to soak for at least 1 hour and up to several hours. To serve this dish chilled, put it in the refrigerator.

itemListElement.text: While soaking, peel the skin of 3 inches daikon radish and grate it.
itemListElement.name: While soaking, peel the skin of 3 inches daikon radish and grate it.

itemListElement.text: Thinly slice 1 green onion/scallion and grate 1 knob ginger.
itemListElement.name: Thinly slice 1 green onion/scallion and grate 1 knob ginger.

itemListElement.text: Put the eggplant pieces in individual serving bowls. Sprinkle with ⅓ cup katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes), then top with the grated daikon and grated ginger. Pour the soaking broth on top of the eggplant pieces (avoiding the toppings) and garnish with green onion. Serve chilled or at room temperature.
itemListElement.name: Put the eggplant pieces in individual serving bowls. Sprinkle with ⅓ cup katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes), then top with the grated daikon and grated ginger. Pour the soaking broth on top of the eggplant pieces (avoiding the toppings) and garnish with green onion. Serve chilled or at room temperature.

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 2–3 days.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 2–3 days.

review.reviewBody: Made this last night to go with the teriyaki salmon. Absolutely delicious! Didn't have daikon so I put grated white carrot and a sprinkle of bonito flakes on top. My oil was sizzling at the beginning but I had the temp a bit too low, so my first couple of pieces turned out gross like you warned in the recipe. The rest were all a great firm and crispy texture. This tasted like a restaurant dish, will make again
Oh I fell in love with eggplants after trying this recipe! They were so delicious! I will cook eggplants more often from now on!

I love the show The Makanai and was craving to do the Eggplant Agebitashi! And so I searched for the recipe at justonecookbook and voila - there's an article all about the show! Thanks Nami! and here I am finding myself commenting for the #justonecookbookchallenge.
I love this recipe so much, and make it regularly. It's like a hug in a bowl, so comforting! My favorite way to eat this is over a bowl of hot rice.
